TI: An endoplasmic reticulum trafficking signal regulates surface expression of beta4 subunit of a voltage- and Ca(2)(+)-activated K(+) channel.
AB: Voltage-dependent and calcium-activated K(+) (MaxiK, BK) channels are widely expressed in many tissues and organs where they play various physiological roles. Here we report discovery of a functional trafficking signal in MaxiK channel accessory beta4 subunit that could regulate activity of MaxiK alpha subunit (hSlo) on the plasma membrane. We demonstrate that beta4 is mostly retained within the cell and removal or mutation of beta4 trafficking signal significantly enhances its surface expression in HEK293T expression system. In hippocampal slices and cultured neurons we also observed significant beta4 expressions within the neurons. Finally, we show that unlike SV1 and beta1 subunits, beta4 shows no dominant-negative effect on MaxiK channel alpha subunit. Taken together, we propose beta4 subunit of MaxiK channel is mostly retained within the cells without interfering with other subunits. Removal of beta4 retention signal increases its surface expression that may lead to reduction of the MaxiK channel activity and neuronal excitability.
